sectionTitle: D.7: Jain Temples and Pilgrimage Places

tabData.tagHTML: Pilgrimage to sacred places, or Tirth Yäträ, is a foundational tradition in Jainism, as it is in many world religions. These journeys are more than just travel; they are a discipline for the body and a way to strengthen one's faith in the company of fellow pilgrims. Praying at a place where great Tirthankars and saints once stood is an inspiring and uplifting experience that brings peace to the mind and merit to the soul.

Jain shrines across India are deeply connected to the lives of the Tirthankars. Places where they were born, attained Dikshä, or achieved Nirväna hold special importance. The art and architecture of these temples, often funded by devout merchants and princes, are a stunning reflection of religious devotion and tell the immortal stories of those who showed the path to liberation.

tabData.title: A Guide to Major Jain Pilgrimage Sites
tabData.description: Explore some of the most significant Jain Tirthas, their locations, and their principal deities (Mulnāyaks).

items.content: Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Ädināth. Located on the magnificent Mt. Shatrunjay, this 'city of temples' has about 900 temples, making it an awe-inspiring spectacle. It is considered an eternal Tirth.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Shankheshwar Pärshvanāth. An ancient and miraculous Tirth, famous for its majestic temple and the divine power of its idol, which is said to heal and protect devotees.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Ädināth. Located on Mount Äbu, the Delwädä temples are world-renowned for their stunning and intricate marble carvings, representing the pinnacle of Jain artistry.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Ädināth. Famed for its grand temple built in the 15th century, which features 1,444 uniquely carved pillars and four entrances, symbolizing a Chaumukha (four-faced) temple.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Bähubali (Gommateshwar). Home to the colossal 57-foot monolithic statue of Lord Bähubali. The Mahä Mastakäbhishek ceremony is held here every 12 years.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Pärshvanāth. The holy land where twenty of the twenty-four Tirthankars attained Nirväna. Every particle of this sacred mountain is considered precious.
Mulnāyak: Foot-idols of Mahävir Swämi. The sacred place where Bhagawän Mahävir attained his Nirväna. The beautiful Jal Mandir (Water Temple) stands in the center of a lotus-filled lake.
Mulnāyak: Bhagawän Nemināth. The site of the Dikshä, Keval-jnän, and Moksh Kalyänaks of the 22nd Tirthankar, Nemināth. This five-peaked mountain is a major pilgrimage site.

events.title: 981 A.D. - Shri Shravanbelgola Tirtha
events.description: The colossal statue of Lord Bähubali is created under the inspiration of Chämundaräy's mother.

events.title: 11th Century - Shri Shankheshwar & Äbu Delwädä
events.description: Major renovation of Shankheshwar is done by Sajjan Shah. At Äbu, the Vimal Vasahi temple is built by Vimal Shah in honor of Bhagawän Ädināth.

events.title: 1128 A.D. - Shri Girnär Tirtha
events.description: The black granite temple of Bhagawän Nemināth is constructed on the first peak of Mount Girnär.

events.title: 1165 A.D. - Shri Tärangä Tirtha
events.description: Under the guidance of Shri Hemchandra Ächārya, King Kumärpäl builds the magnificent temple of Bhagawän Ajitnäth.

events.title: 1230 A.D. - Shri Äbu Delwädä Tirtha
events.description: The Lunaga Vasahi temple is built by the brothers Vastupäl and Tejpäl in honor of Bhagawän Nemināth. Tejpäl's wife, Anupamä-devi, supervises the construction.

events.title: 15th Century - Shri Ranakpur Tirtha
events.description: During the reign of Ränä Kumbha, the Jain businessman Dharna Shah builds the grand, three-story temple of Ranakpur.

events.title: 1760 A.D. - Shri Shankheshwar Tirtha
events.description: The vast and beautiful temple of Shankheshwar is expanded to include 52 surrounding small temples.

events.title: 1766 A.D. - Shri Sametshikhar Tirtha
events.description: Following an auspicious dream, Sheth Khushaldas of Murshidabad builds small temples with foot-idols at the exact Nirväna locations of the Tirthankars.

events.title: 1934 A.D. - Shri Sametshikhar Tirtha
events.description: With the inspiration of Ächārya Sägaränand Suri, the Tirth undergoes its 23rd major renovation.

tabData.title: Feats of Art and Sculpture
tabData.description: Jain temples are renowned for their breathtaking artistry. Explore some of the most famous examples.

items.header: Äbu Delwädä: The Epitome of Marble Carving
items.content:
The Delwädä temples are famous for their stunning use of white marble. The carving is so minute and delicate that it appears translucent. Key features include:
  • Rang Mandap: A grand hall with a breathtaking central dome and 12 decorated pillars.
  • Navchowki: A collection of nine rectangular ceilings, each with unique and beautiful designs.
  • Deräni-Jethäni Niches: Found in the Lunaga Vasahi temple, these recesses show exceptional and delicate marble cutting.

The temple at Ranakpur is an architectural wonder, renowned for its scale and complexity. Key features include:
  • 1,444 Pillars: The temple is supported by over 1,444 intricately carved columns, and no two are alike.
  • Uninterrupted View: The pillars are arranged so skillfully that the main idol is visible from any spot within the temple.
  • Intricate Carvings: The temple features countless sculptures, including a famous stone slab depicting a thousand-hooded snake sheltering Lord Pärshvanāth.

The 57-foot statue of Lord Bähubali is carved from a single stone (monolith). Its beautifully chiseled features express deep serenity and detachment, making it an outstanding example of Indian sculpture.

tabData.title: Lands of Auspicious Events
tabData.description: Certain Tirthas are especially holy as they are the sites of multiple Kalyänaks of different Tirthankars.

cards.back: The site of the Chyavan, birth, and Dikshä Kalyänaks of Bhagawän Ädināth, and four Kalyänaks each for Ajitnāth, Abhinandan Swāmi, Sumatināth, and Anantnāth.
The site of four Kalyänaks (all but Nirväna) for Bhagawän Shāntināth, Kunthunāth, and Aranāth. It is also where Rishabhadev broke his year-long fast.
The place of Bhagawän Mahävir's final sermon and his Nirväna Kalyänak, making it one of the most sacred sites.
The site of the Dikshä, Keval-jnän, and Nirväna Kalyänaks of the 22nd Tirthankar, Bhagawän Nemināth.
Known as the land of Nirväna, where an incredible twenty Tirthankars attained their final liberation (Nirväna Kalyänak).
